reviewText:
I could likely sum up this entire review by simply stating the title of the game in question: Yet Another Zombie Defense. Intended as a sideways joke at the ridiculous number of zombie themed games flooding the market, it extends beyond the name to every aspect of the game, resulting in a bland and unimaginative isometric shooter that even for the low price is hardly worth a second glance.

If you've ever played a wave based survival shooter you already know exactly how YAZD functions. Enemies come at you in increasingly difficult swarms, which you then counter by buying guns and defense in between rounds. Rinse, repeat, and try to stay alive as long as you can. It's a formula that's been done dozens of times over, but when executed properly can be immensely addictive and rewarding.

You can probably see where I'm going with this, so I'll just spell it out: YAZD doesn't get it right. A surface summarization of the many games that inspired it, it has the right pieces to potentially make a great game but doesn't know how to use them effectively. Progression is severely limited and uninteresting, with only a handful of unimpressive guns to choose from and even fewer defenses, as well as no upgrade system or other means to provide something to keep playing for beyond a highscore. Enemies are repetitive to far too great a degree, making for a dull experience after the first few waves as you begin to go through the motions, and the banal presentation leaves a great deal to be desired.

To be perfectly fair, YAZD isn't broken on any fundamental level, it's just not fun. Everything it attempts has already been done infinitely better in so many other games, that I can't bring myself to recommend it for even a quick look. There's an argument to be made for it being cheap so expectations are obviously lowered, but personally I would recommend spending a bit more and getting something more polished and deserving of your time. You might be able to squeeze an hour of enjoyment out of it with a friend if you really try, but that doesn't make up Yet Another Zombie Defense being as hollow and lifeless as the undead it pits against you.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

Short Review

Ever heard of Orion: Prelude? Terrible launch game with infinite amount of bug and generally unpleasant gameplay that got relaunched not once but 3 times but eventually end up somewhat good enough to play and cheap enough to justify the few remaining bugs?

Well Yet Another Zombie Defense is a bit like that except it never got relaunched, there was hardly any bugs, the graphics are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and contents are barebone. Yet I am actually recommending it because:

A) It does what it say it does well which is a horde based game defending against zombie.
B) It was already super cheap to begin with.
And C) It actually got updated.

At its core Yet Another Zombie defense is a topdown shooter that has you defending a highly important streetlight for as long possible and to accomplish this you kill zombies to get money for turrets, barricades, ammo and more guns with random drops happening throughout the match. It used to be that the game has practically zero content but now it has more turret and barricade types and far more stable netcode.

What more could you ask for about a game defending a streetlight probably covered in meat from the undead horde? For the cost of a couple of high value cards you and your mate could probably enjoy this stupid thing for a few hours and thats more than enough in my book.

Yet Another Zombie Defense is a small, unpretentious game that manages to do what it wants to do quite well. The objective is very clear: defend yourself against ever increasing hordes of attacting zombies (hey - that's in the title!). So I went into it, as in quite some of these small and cheap games, I do admit, for the trading cards, and since I love games with Steam achievements. reviewText:
Yet ANOTHER zombie defense is a decent entry in the zombie/survival genre despite the over-saturation of zombie games in recent years.

STORY & GAMEPLAY
Choosing one of three characters, you must survive for as long as possible by constructing and buying resources by day and defending by night either alone, or with friends and strangers up to four players.

The game presents you with an assortment of weapons and accessories to aid you in your zombie slaughter. Ideally in zombie shooters the most expensive weapon is the most effective. That concept is no different on Yet Another Zombie Defense: Expensive = Effective. You can either buy weapons during day break at full price, or wait for a discounted sale to hit in later days. You will burn through money fast; therefore sales provide you with an option to cash in on low-price gear. You can effectively create your own ‚Äúsafe zone‚Äù through the use of auto-turrets and two variants of palisade walls: Wood and steel - the latter being more durable to zombie attacks. You can have all sorts of combinations, though their effectiveness will be tested in combat.

The online portion works just as well as the single player with a drop in/drop out feature. I had some lag drops here and there, even during my own hosted lobbies though not too often that would ruin the overall experience. Players can communicate via the in-game chat box and host is able to kick players who are otherwise trolling or lack contribution. From the several games I played the community is rather active, friendly and helpful which is a major plus.

The current offering is satisfying, though for a limited time. The game lacks weapon/fortification upgrades and variation in terms of maps. Once you breach wave 20 you will stop and question whether it is possible to progress any further as zombies become ridiculously over-powered in terms of speed, durability and damage. Future updates are promised by the developer (most recent being 14 August 2014) possibly free of charge, therefore it would be nice to introduce additional features to build on the current game.

I only played this game with an Xbox controller, therefore cannot comment on the functionality of keyboard and mouse. Xbox controls handled well without any problems.

GRAPHICS / ART STYLE
Aesthetically nothing impressive. The character and zombie models are almost identical to those in Garry‚Äôs Mod. Delivers an entertaining game of mindless zombie killing.

AUDIO
Between 4-5 different tracks; nothing major in terms of variety. Some sound effects were off-sync ‚Äì i.e weapon shots and zombie growls.

OVERALL
A fun but limited zombie shooter with a not-so-ridiculous price tag. In dire need of additional content to bolster its current offerings.

PROS
+Two modes which can be played alone or co-op + supported by leaderboards.
+Nice assortment of weapons and tools to change gameplay.
+Ridiculously cheap.
+Developer is opposed to the idea of charging players for additional content (DLC).

CONS
-In dire need of additional content ‚Äì especially map variations.
-Unexplainable lag in single player and online.
-Some sound effects off-sync.

reviewText:
Yet Another Zombie Defense is as the title suggests, a zombie defense. I can't really say much about this game, but I guess I'll start at the price. This game is quite affordable at the price of ¬£1.59, although I got this in a sale for ¬£0.39, and I'd say that it's most likely worth it. The game's design isn't unique or out of the norm, but it doesn't go to say that it's a bad game, at all. The zombies work well and don't bug from my experiences so far, nor do the items for sale (guns, barricades, turrets, etc). However, there was an issue that happened to me a few times, and really annoyed me. After 'daytime', when the night starts and swarms of zombies attack, occasionally your character would not be able to move or equip any weapons other than the starter weapon, the pistol. Only being able to use the starter gun and look around isn't good, especially if you've progressed really far by yourself; just a side note, the map isn't really that large. I'd love to see a new map added that was much larger and had run down buildings in which you could put turrets in.

The Co-Op is good. There's Multiplayer, Singleplayer and Local Co-Op, the Steam Trading Cards, Leaderboards and Full Controller support add to why I believe this game is good. There are 3 Characters, the 'SWAT', 'Boy' and 'Girl', which aren't too imaginative and do not have any personalities. There aren't many online lobbies, but playing with friends or hosting a lobby is still pretty fun. To add to that, there are 3 game modes, all of which I like.

I'd recommend this for people looking for a quick game to pick up and play; like I previously said, there's not a whole lot to say about this game, it's not bad, but it doesn't stand out well. I enjoyed playing this game myself and would recommend this game to those considering buying it.

reviewText:
Saw this was ¬£0.39 on Steam (75% off) and thought YOLO how bad could it be!

This game is actually pretty good for a small simple game that it is. The goal is to survive hordes of zombies trying to kill you and you have some variety of weapons and defenses to help you.

There are two game modes, Defense and Endless Night.

Defense

First of all you can choose to play solo or allow others to join you when choosing this game mode or you can choose to find a game hosted by another player. Playing with others does help survivability however only the host can buy items such as walls, weapons, turrets and ammo.

You start with only a pistol to defend yourself and earn $ by killing zombies. You can buy weapons, walls and even turrets which can have any weapon mounted on them as you see fit. You do need to make sure that you buy ammo for all of the guns that are in use however because turrets will be useless if they are not shooting because of ammo shortages. In the later levels repairing walls and resupplying ammo can start to get very expensive since the zombies also progressively get faster, tougher and stronger.

The area you have to build is a little smaller than the edge of the map where the zombies will be spawning and you have a single lamppost in the center of the map providing some light. The very edge of the map is an invisible barrier and zombies will just spawn instantly so can occasionally block you if you happen to be running the edge of the map.

Lastly the items that you can buy to help your survivability sometimes can be bought slightly cheaper because they go 'on sale' which can be helpful but sometimes it can take a while for them to do so, in which case it might be more viable to buy them at their full prices.

Endless Night Mode

In this mode you can also choose to play solo or allow others to join you when choosing this game mode or you can choose to find a game hosted by another player. Again playing with others can help survivability but in this mode you cannot build defenses, you can only run around so make sure not to run into each other with a horde of zombies either side of you and get trapped!

This game mode runs 'endlessly' until you die, there is no daytime in which you can buy weapons or defenses or ammo, there is just one single night that lasts until you die. You can however pick up weapons dropped by zombies upon their death but the ammo is very limited for these so you will run out and your pistol (which has infinite ammo) will be pulled out again.

Overall

Great game for only ¬£0.39 that i bought it for, does have achievements that took me only 5 hours to achieve but its a very simple fun game and for that price you can not go wrong!

For reviewing completeness the game does also have Steam Badges if you are interested in those too!

reviewText:
It's way too simple. That's the fault. The actual gameplay is solid enough, and actually feels cleaner than some other isometric arcade shooters I've played (more expensive ones to boot). The survival aspect isn't bad, since you actually do have to utilize barricades and whatnot if you want to survive at later levels, because zombies increasingly become faster, stronger, and more durable. At first you can just kite the circular play area and the few zombies who decide to run faster towards you can be taken care of easily, while you outrun the rest and pick them off later. Further on, though, when the zombies all have high speed levels, you can't outrun them for long, and you have to either kill the quick moving ones immediately, or use barricades to hold them off and survive.

For the asking price (dirt cheap, or free in a past free Indie Royale Bundle), it's actually a really clean feeling game. It's just lacking in depth and variation. The developer is always asking for feedback on the game, suggestions, etc, and says he'll add more upgrades, game modes, etc if there's enough interest.

Everyone was bashing this dev, but to be honest, he's doing things the correct way. He didn't bite off more than he could chew, he made a simple, playable game with good fundamentals and nice clean graphics, and will add to it from there. Much better than so many other indie devs who bite off way more than they can chew and put out a glitchy, unplayable piece of crap, or ones who make up for their lack of skill by making things too weird and 2deep4u, or getting lazy with retro" graphics.

reviewText:
Yet Another Zombie Defense is a fairly simple top down twin stick shooter with some tower defense elements thrown in. Basically, you are thown in with nothing but a pistol and fight off a wave of zombies. These are the nights. Then, once they're all dead, it goes into a section where you can use the cash you earned from killing zombies to purchase and build. These are the days. You can buy guns, ammo, turrets to place guns on that will shoot automatically, and walls that can be placed to help stop the incoming waves. During the night stages you can pick up drops from the zombies like ammo crates, money stacks, and full health. Health will come back between rounds, but if run out of it during the night, it's game over. The walls and guns become very necessary for later rounds as the zombies continue to increase not only in numbers, but in speed and health as well. You're going to die. It's just about how long you can survive. Eventually ammo will run out, walls will get destroyed, and you'll be overwhelmed. And that's basically the whole game. Simple, but with possibilities and strategies to try. Oh, and there's an endless mode with is similar except that... there's no day stages.

There's also mutliplayer, which is where this game really shines for me. You can play with up to three other people (meaning four players total including yourself). That means four times the firepower, and a game is only over if every member dies so... better odds. Just make sure not to get in each other's way and do your best to cooperate. Playing online is a great way to make this game more enjoyable and interesting, as you can see other people's skills and strategies. I've played much more online multiplayer with this game than single player, and it's one of the few games I actually play online anymore.

I also want to mention how cool some of the other things are in this game. It has some neat music, which is nice. The way you can build walls and turrets to create a defensive outpost between rounds is a lot like a tower defense game, and it's a cool way to implement that genre into this top down twin stick shooter type of game. It's basically what I think a new arcade game would be like. I like it.

But every game has some downsides. The online can be awfully laggy at times. That can be due to distance, but... it's still a major drag since there's no local co op for this game, another downside. Also, while graphically it looks alright, artistically it is a bit drab. It's a zombie apocalypse, I get it, but that doesn't mean I have to like the dark, dirty look. Just a personal preference thing I suppose. Also, there's this weird system that allows everyone to use the money to buy things in private games with friends, but in random online matches there's no way to do so. Only the host can buy things. It works out alright, but the fact that it's inconsistent is strange to me, and not really explained anywhere either. The heads up would help. Speaking of that, it'd also be nice to get a little warning on the turrets. See, you buy the turrets from the shop and then you can place them. Pretty easy to figure out. What's confusing is that you're supposed to mount a gun on them. This could've been conveyed a little better. Many times newcomers will buy a turret and place it then be confused as to why it won't shoot. Well you have to have another gun to mount on it. And that gun also uses ammo. You start with many extra pistols to mount to them, which is nice enough, but being given a small heads up on a few of these features might have been nice little things to add. Also, there are supposedly more updates coming... but they're taking long than expected as well as longer than announced. So don't base your purchase on new features coming as it's still a bit up in the air. However, let it be noted that, at the very least, more stages to pick from would be very appreciated.

It's still a pretty fun little game. Nice for a time killer. Simple. Easy to learn. And for two bucks, it's worth it. Wait for a sale even. I got it cheaper and even I think it's worth the full price. Yet Another Zombie Defense gets a 6/10 for being a fun, simple, arcadey experience in a more modern time.

reviewText:
Within the time I've played this game, it helps pass the time. It's like a basic tycoon game in which you can earn money as you kill zombies. As you progress, the zombies become stronger and more lethal. Trying to survive 10 nights might seem difficult enough, but getting at any point past night 10 is difficult if you have less than four people. Trying to get all the achievements can be a challenge and makes more goals to go after in this game. What I liked most about this game is the accessibility to auto-turrents and the ability to mount any weapon on top of them, making them fierce allies if you're able to protect them. My personal favorite weapon is the Telsa Ray, which can attack up to three zombies at once, and is basically an instant-kill gun. I love the idea of ammo sharing and whenever some gains a health pack you get some of it too. It was definitely worth the $0.69 I paid for. Even though I currently only have 2.6 hours on it, I expect to add more, seeing a this is an enjoyable game to play.

Some things to know before you play:
You can have up to 4 people playing with you.
You can customize your server to personnal or to public
The game becomes harder as you play
It matters where you place everything
The Rocket Launcher is not a good gun
The auto turrents are VERY useful
At random nights, there are sales on various item in the store
Never play alone
The street light is your friend

Some thing that could be added:
Better assortment of weapons
New barricades
Possibly new maps
New characters
New game mode (Example: A defending mode where you have to protect the street lamp from the zombies.)
Few various tweaks on the AIs of the zombies
Voice chat in the game
And maybe a few bosses that come out each night during the horde, to add a little spice to the game!

I hope this helped you and gave you a proper decision on whether to buy this game or not, but I will say this; It is defininetly worth the amount of money it is being sold for, very fun and low graphics, meaning you can have a fast gameplay on slow laptops, like mine! Enjoy the game!

reviewText:
Surprisingly fun wave-based shooter. It's simple, yet still entertaining
You start with a pistol, and shoot zombies wave after wave. Not so original, but the game is very aware of that, hence the name.

You can play the game Solo, or Online up to 4-players Co-op.
No problems with multiplayer, works fine!

After each wave, you can place defenses, such as barricades and turrets.
With some planning you can get quite far, but it does require you to try few times.

Achievements are pretty easy to get, I got all 100% in few hours. Some you might get without thinking about it, but others may need few tries to get. There are steam guides for achievements, so that helps.

Overall, it's fun zombie shooter which brings nothing new to the genre, but is still entertaining for few hours in small sessions. Price is low, and you can pick it up on sale for even cheaper. Definitely worth the asking price.

reviewText:
YAZD is a very limited an simplistic game in the same mould of Nation Red.  Basically you play one character in an 3rd person arena shooter where you must take on and defeat wave after wave of harder enemies.  The longer you survive the higher your score. Though unlike the excellent NR, YAZD has only one map, no perks, one type of enemy and very limited replayability.  Infact once you've made the achievements there is almost nothing to bring you back.  Except maybe getting the best score on the leaderboard.

There are three character types to choose from but none of them have any diffrenciating abilities.  Between each way you can buy new weapons to shoot down the waves of enemies.  In addition to your starting pistol these include: SMG, shotgun, flamethrower, assault rifle, sniper rifle, rocket launcher, laser and tesla coil.  These weapons can be mounted on automated turrets to increase the number of weapons firing during a wave but, at a cost.  Defensive obstacles can be brought to construct a temporary base to increase of survival.

Perhaps its one true plus is the coop for up to four players but even then the session leader is the only one who purchase the weapons for the team.  Where its different from say Nation Red is that ammo must also be purchased for each weapon.  If this runs out during a wave you only have your basic pistol to rely on.  Which means almost certain death after wave 5.

Gameplay is very repetitive but can be fun in short bursts.  Though eventually you'll succumb to its limited capabilities and uninstall.  Be warned - Only recommended on a 75%+ discount, 90% if you can find it.

This was the best 75 cents of my entire life. For those who want a full review, read on. Otherwise, I give the game a 9/10 for a low price and fun gameplay.

I found this game randomly, saw it was 75 cents for a two pack (ON SALE), and instantly got it thinking it would be only decent, but it's actually really good! This is a very simple game, and as such it is not very difficult to learn the different mechanics. As the title may suggest, this game is about defending yourself from zombies, but it's in a third person perspective and it's done pretty well overall. This game offers two gamemodes, which are Defense and Endless Night (which can be unlocked by getting to night 7 of Defense). The 3 characters are Guy, Girl, and Swat, and they do not (as far as I've seen) have any difference between them. I think it would be cool to add some special characteristics to make the characters different; such as the Guy having more Defense, the Girl having more Speed, and the Swat having more Damage or Firing Speed. Every Night in Defense mode you can buy upgrades like fences or weapons, and so you evolve from night to night. But as expected, the zombies slowly get more challenging too. This game is a masterpiece for the asking price of as little as 50 cents for a copy, and is still fun. For those who have that little amount of money in their steam wallet, I highly recommend getting this game. It's lots of fun.

reviewText:
YAZD is a very limited an simplistic game in the same mould of Nation Red.  Basically you play one character in an 3rd person arena shooter where you must take on and defeat wave after wave of harder enemies.  The longer you survive the higher your score. Though unlike the excellent NR, YAZD has only one map, no perks, one type of enemy and very limited replayability.  Infact once you've made the achievements there is almost nothing to bring you back.  Except maybe getting the best score on the leaderboard.

There are three character types to choose from but none of them have any diffrenciating abilities.  Between each way you can buy new weapons to shoot down the waves of enemies.  In addition to your starting pistol these include: SMG, shotgun, flamethrower, assault rifle, sniper rifle, rocket launcher, laser and tesla coil.  These weapons can be mounted on automated turrets to increase the number of weapons firing during a wave but, at a cost.  Defensive obstacles can be brought to construct a temporary base to increase of survival.

Perhaps its one true plus is the coop for up to four players but even then the session leader is the only one who purchase the weapons for the team.  Where its different from say Nation Red is that ammo must also be purchased for each weapon.  If this runs out during a wave you only have your basic pistol to rely on.  Which means almost certain death after wave 5.

Gameplay is very repetitive but can be fun in short bursts.  Though eventually you'll succumb to its limited capabilities and uninstall.  Be warned - Only recommended on a 75%+ discount, 90% if you can find it.

reviewText:
Summary: Inexpensive twin-stick overhead defense.
Multiplayer: 4 Online Co-op
Completion: Never ends, but death is likely within 1 hour.
Cards: Yes
Cloud: No

Yet Another Zombie Defense is as its name implies. It's an overhead twin-stick shooter game where you spend each day shooting zombies who seem to have an uncanny knack for knowing where you are. The game plays on a single, large parking lot with a lone street lamp to keep you company as you gun down masses of ever-increasing zombies who become faster, stronger, and more durable with each passing day. Killing zombies provides you with funds with which to buy new guns, ammo, turrets, and fences (Who's selling these? Ah who cares).

The graphics are serviceable. They look like they were designed with the bare minimum. I haven't experienecd any slowdown, so that's a good sign. Collision detection is a little spotty, as it can be hard to tell when you get hit, and fences act a bit weird on how you can walk past them. As for the music, I hope you like combat and build phase songs because those are the only two songs you will ever hear. They're not bad, but you will almost certainly want to put on some other tunes after you've heard them a few times.

Endless mode is a nice change of pace for when you get tired of the same gameplay. In it, you cannot purchase anything and must make do with random drops provided by the zombies. It's all kiting the old-fashioned way. Overall the standard game is much more satisfying to play though.

The best way to enjoy this game by far is with friends. This game was meant for co-op survival and to that end it does it very well. No matter how good you are you're going to die, as the zombies scale much faster than you. Your cash reserves are pooled together, so it's best to play with someone you can trust, as sometimes strangers are unaware of this fact and spend your cash by accident.

So the big question is, is it worth it? Yup, this is one game I can recommend even at full price, just because of how inexpensive it is. The return value in entertainment is quite good, and having friends to play it with makes it all the better. Surprisingly YAZD is updated from time to time, so it can be worth coming back to after a long hiatus to find out what's new.  I rate this game a 8.5/10 for its nice combination of affordability, multiplayer, and fun.

reviewText:
Yet Another Zombie Defense is quite a simplistic but very fun game. The game offers two types of game modes.

Defense
Endless Night
The basis of the first game mode Defense is to 'build your base by day and defend it by night'. This game mode is basically wave defense, every wave the zombies get faster, more health and deal more damage. This means that the standard pistol that you start off with will no longer be doing any real damage to the zombie horde. Another possible inconvenience to factor in is the lamp-post, the lamp-post is your only source of light in this game which means you will most likely be building your base around this lamp. There are 12 means of defense, these include; the wooden and steel palisades, the autoturret, pistol, SMG, Shotgun, Flamethrower, Assault rifle, Sniper rifle, Rocket launcher, Tesla coil and the Laser. Each of these weapons and defense mechanisms costs cash from which you gain killing zombies and collecting random drops off their dead bodies. All of these means of defense go on sale randomly through the waves which is quite cool, as if you are $2,000 off buying the laser and it goes on sale the wave after, you can purchase instead of going through another round without it. The cost of ammo is variable through the weapons however they generally cost $40-80 although the flame thrower is more at $200. Once again, these can go on sale and you can also loot them randomly off zombie corpses.

The other mode Endless Nights is about 'fighting zombies in never ending darkness'. In this mode the base-building and shopping element to the game is dropped, for a more shoot-em-up style of gaming. But don't worry, just because you can no longer shop for your favourite weapons, it doesn't mean that they won't drop from the zombies as they crumple to the floor. I mean, who doesn't love having a rocket launcher after thirty seconds? During this game mode you will most likely find yourself frantically running around the map trying to avoid the zombies but also trying to gun them down one-by-one. As in both game modes, there are three characters available to choose from; the guy, the girl and the swat.

The game is quite entertaining although it is best played with friends to maximize the most fun you can have with it. I have played both game modes with and without friends and they are both enjoyable. The game is a port from the Xbox 360 version and plays quite well on my system and also offers full controller support. The system requirements are also generally quite low so that is always nice to see with games. Lastly, the multiplayer is very easy and quick to set up and have others join, which is a positive due to the fact that some games these days are very difficult to set up.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who likes relaxing, simple and enjoyable zombie games. Although I would not recommend the game at the current price as on sale, it becomes a lot more cheaper! Depending on your region, the price for a 2-pack would be ¬£0.49 / $0.74 / ‚Ç¨0.49 and at this price I would immediately recommend it.

reviewText:
Summary: Inexpensive twin-stick overhead defense.
Multiplayer: 4 Online Co-op
Completion: Never ends, but death is likely within 1 hour.
Cards: Yes
Cloud: No

Yet Another Zombie Defense is as its name implies. It's an overhead twin-stick shooter game where you spend each day shooting zombies who seem to have an uncanny knack for knowing where you are. The game plays on a single, large parking lot with a lone street lamp to keep you company as you gun down masses of ever-increasing zombies who become faster, stronger, and more durable with each passing day. Killing zombies provides you with funds with which to buy new guns, ammo, turrets, and fences (Who's selling these? Ah who cares).

The graphics are serviceable. They look like they were designed with the bare minimum. I haven't experienecd any slowdown, so that's a good sign. Collision detection is a little spotty, as it can be hard to tell when you get hit, and fences act a bit weird on how you can walk past them. As for the music, I hope you like combat and build phase songs because those are the only two songs you will ever hear. They're not bad, but you will almost certainly want to put on some other tunes after you've heard them a few times.

Endless mode is a nice change of pace for when you get tired of the same gameplay. In it, you cannot purchase anything and must make do with random drops provided by the zombies. It's all kiting the old-fashioned way. Overall the standard game is much more satisfying to play though.

The best way to enjoy this game by far is with friends. This game was meant for co-op survival and to that end it does it very well. No matter how good you are you're going to die, as the zombies scale much faster than you. Your cash reserves are pooled together, so it's best to play with someone you can trust, as sometimes strangers are unaware of this fact and spend your cash by accident.

So the big question is, is it worth it? Yup, this is one game I can recommend even at full price, just because of how inexpensive it is. The return value in entertainment is quite good, and having friends to play it with makes it all the better. Surprisingly YAZD is updated from time to time, so it can be worth coming back to after a long hiatus to find out what's new.  I rate this game a 8.5/10 for its nice combination of affordability, multiplayer, and fun.

Go to steam library, properties of the game, find the button to view game files, rightclick on the executable and make sure it is set to launch with graphics card by default.

reviewText:
When I first got into this game, it was half a dollar. For such a low price I expected a low quality game with no longevity whatsoever. Granted, I still think it may not provide the longevity some gamers long for(IT DOES HAVE REPLAY VALUE, but it is definitely fun.
A simple zombie defense game, that doesn't require any additional effort to play online(like downloading Hamachi).

Pros:
-Few noticeable bugs(other than wanky character models)
-Easy to host, connect, and randomly join your friends or random people
-Can be played casually, but has a rather large skill gap because of the room for strategic play(That's a biggie for hardcore gamers)
-Very simple concept
-Easy to get into
-Very little PC power needed to run
-Promotes cooperative play
-Replay value
-No additional effort for connecting to players

Cons:
-Inconsiderate, inept, worthless, wastes of oxygen(Scrub hosts).
-When playing online, all the money is shared amongst everyone, but only host can spend it, so that tends to result in
greedy misfortune
-There is no host migration feature(If the player hosting quits, the entire game ends)
-Does not promote playing with randoms
-There is a grace period between each zombie wave(which is nice), but if the host doesn't want a break, he gets to skip
the entire grace period. Not only that but there is a very small respawn delay for the zombies, so if you have the
misfortune of scrub-based matchmaking, you will not get a grace period(no time to speak in chat with other players)

Overall, it is a great game, and for a low price, you can go sell a few trading cards and come back for it.
I do highly recommend this game only if you play solo, with friends, or happen to find decent competent people.

Thank you for reading, have a great life.

Yet Another Zombie Defense is a zombie survival game with co-op and uses the wave mechanics.

Negatives

reviewText:
So, let's define what a typical video game zombie horde is:

1) Dumb as a rock
2) Highly predictable
3) Extremely numerous
4) Individually fragile

Frankly, this game's biggest failure is that, instead of just making the zomibes more numerous, which would make sense, they make them individually stronger AND more numerous. Hey, kids, want to play a game where each of the 60 on-screen zombies take a whole assault rifle clip to kill? Where the basic weapons are vastly more effective than the advanced ones? Well, you're in luck, because this game exists.

In a nutshell: If you're looking for something to tie into a drinking game at your next LAN party, you might get a few kicks from this. Otherwise, you're looking at 20-30 minutes of entertainment for your 2$. It could be fun with weaker zombies, and with more weapons and features, but if you just -really- need your zombie survival fix, go play Unturned instead.

reviewText:
A very simple flash game that doesn't try to complicate anything, just run point and shoot at stuff. You can place barricades and turrets and use money gained from killing zombies to buy new weapons, from shotguns to lasers.

Pros:
- Decent selection of weapons
- Easy to jump into games
- Fun to play with friends, and just as fun with randoms
- Well priced

Neutrals:
- Simple gameplay and limited defense items, but can be good for someone looked for quick and easy games and boring to anyone looking for more
- Becomes very difficult after wave 18, good for people looking for a challenge and bad for people who spent the game setting up defense for them to be shattered

Cons:
- Graphics are very plain
- Low replayability after one or two rounds, finding myself being bored after 40 minutes to an hour

A cheap flash game with time keeping, achievements and trading cards that can hold its own for its low price, if your bored and want to meet new people or just want a simple zombie defense to play with your friends, pick it up.

Personal Rating: 3/5

Actually YAZD is a pretty good game. Now, this is being said in consideration that this is an indie game, meaining it won't have as good graphics, it may not have original sounds or even soundtracks, and it just overall won't be that one game you always play (sometimes). YAZD however, does not in my opinion fall into the last critique.

The gameplay, the bread of the entire indie sandwich, is very straightforward and easy to get used to. You move around with (for gamepad users) the left stick, shoot with right trigger, and aim with right stick. Aiming is pretty on point and you hit your target 98 times out of 100.

The sounds should be split into two categories: sound effects and soundtracks. The sound effects are okay, not too many of them and the ones that are there aren't the best, but keep in mind that this is an inide game, right? The actual soundtracks, the music playing as you zombie defend, is the same one every round. While in the main menu and in daytime there is a second soundtrack, but it's kind of corny with the same Darkness... is coming..." opreatic repeated over and over.
